Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Proposal: ARTS: Revisionary systematics of fossil and living Caribbean faviid and mussid reef corals (Cnidaria, Anthozoa, Scleractinia)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Coral reefs are among the most diverse marine ecosystems and are increasingly threatened by climate change, ocean acidification, overfishing, and anthropogenic disturbance. They are constructed by 18 families and >800 species of reef-building coral. The traditional classification scheme of reef-building corals based on macromorphology indicate that few groups have distributions limited to the Caribbean. Recent molecular analyses, however, disagree with the traditional classification and have identified a previously unrecognized, exclusively Caribbean lineage. These findings indicate reef-building corals are in need of a complete re-evaluation. This collaborative project will assess the diversity and clarify the taxonomy and relationships between a group of Caribbean reef corals from related Mediterranean and Indo-Pacific species beginning ~55 million years ago. The project will analyze 79 living and ~380 fossil species. Molecular and morphological datasets will be integrated for the first time, and include novel microscopic features. The evolutionary history of Caribbean reefs will be reconstructed, and the effects of past biogeographic events on present-day biodiversity will be assessed.

A postdoctoral scholar, graduate student, and four undergraduates will be trained in coral systematics. Results will be publically disseminated through peer-reviewed publications and electronic sources via an online taxonomic database, Neogene Marine Biota of Tropical America (NMITA) (http://nmita.iowa.uiowa.edu/), and the Encyclopedia of Life (http://eol.org). Project results will influence conservation priorities that are based on species numbers without consideration of evolutionary distinctiveness.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Coral reefs are among the most diverse marine ecosystems and are increasingly threatened by climate change, ocean acidification, and anthropogenic disturbance. They are constructed by >800 species of reef-building coral, traditionally grouped into 17 families based on macromorphology. However, molecular results disagree on which species belong to at least 11 families. Moreover, traditional taxonomy indicates that Indo-Pacific and Caribbean families are closely related; whereas molecular analyses suggest a previously unrecognized, exclusively Caribbean family.

 

The project integrated morphological, molecular, and paleontological data and performed analyses reconstructing evolutionary trees for five traditional families (167 or 26% of the living species diversity of the stony coral order Scleractinia). New micromorphological features were discovered and improved tree resolution. Based on the results, the five families were reduced to three (one Caribbean, two Indo-Pacific), and four monographs were published formally revising the systematics of each family. The role of biogeography in the origin of the Caribbean family was investigated by comparing 23-45 million year old Caribbean and Mediterranean fossils (~50 fossil species), and monographing the Mediterranean fossils. In this interval of geologic history, a tropical seaway extended around the globe connecting Indo-Pacific, Mediterranean, and Caribbean reef-building corals. Due to subsequent geographic and environmental changes in the Mediterranean, reef-building corals became extinct in that region approximately 5 million years ago.  Our findings indicate that the 23-45 million year old Mediterranean fossils were more closely related to Indo-Pacific corals, and that the Caribbean corals represent a distinct lineage that originated in isolation as the Atlantic widened. Contrary to traditional taxonomy, the Caribbean corals are evolutionarily distinct. This distinctiveness has implications for setting priorites in marine conservation.


One postdoctoral scholar, three graduate students, and three undergraduates were trained in coral systematics. Results were publically disseminated through 11 peer-reviewed publications and through electronic sources via the online taxonomic databases, Neogene Marine Biota of Tropical America (NMITA) (nmita.iowa.uiowa.edu/) and Corallosphere (corallosphere.org). Project results support conservation priorities that are based on evolutionary distinctiveness.
